Andrew,

Thanks for that link.  I'll have to look into kintecus a little 
m=
ore.  It looks like Kilpinen et. al have done a fair amount of work 
with b=
iomass.  Their mechanism, however does not appear to have 
species such as =
a cellulose monomer or lignin which are essential to 
modeling partial oxid=
ation of biomass.  

Paul



--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, "Andrew Mackro=
ry" 
<andrew.mackrory@...> wrote:
>
> The Kintecus chemical simulation soft=
ware available at
> http://www.kintecus.com/  has a mechanism available for=
 it that may 
be
> useful to you. Kintecus is based on Excel input, so ther=
e would be 
some
> manual translation of the mechanism from the Excel forma=
t to 
Cantera format
> but it shouldn't be too hard.
> http://www.kintecus.=
org/Kilpinen_97_NH3_ORG.xls appears to me to be 
the
> mechanism from Energ=
y & Fuels, Vol. 14, No. 4, 2000 with extra 
reactions
> added. The mechanis=
m from E&F is for biomass-derived gasification 
gas. I had
> a quick look a=
nd couldn't Lorenzo's reactions, then I realized that 
they are
> not eleme=
ntary reactions, so maybe a few of the reactions from the 
mechanism
> are =
equivalent to one of your reactions.
> Hope this is helpful to you.
> Andre=
w
> 
> 
> On 7/26/07, Paul <bio.evans@...> wrote:
> >
> >   Lorenzo,
> >
> =
> I am also interested in the kinetics of biomass gasification and
> > pyro=
lysis. The biggest challenge will be coming up with a kinetic
> > mechanism=
. Most of the mechanisms available describe combustion of
> > hydrocarbons =
and typically don't include molecules typical of 
biomass
> > gasification =
(i.e. large oxygenated cyclic compounds).
> >
> > Cantera is a tool for mod=
eling reaction kinetics, but it needs 
input
> > from the user (in the form=
 of the kinetic mechanism) to tell it 
which
> > reactions to consider and =
what their rates are.
> >
> > If you find a mechanism that's already been d=
eveloped I'd love to
> > hear about it.
> >
> > --- In cantera@yahoogroups.=
com <cantera%40yahoogroups.com>,
> > "lorenzo_damiani"
> > <lorenzo_damiani=
@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hello,
> > >
> > > I am a PhD Student, and I am worki=
ng on biomass gasification
> > > modeling. A colleague told me about Canter=
a, and described it 
as a
> > > powerful device for reactors modeling: I do=
wnloaded it 
immediately!
> > >
> > > As I am intended to implement a kinet=
ic model for biomass
> > > gasification, I would like to understand what is=
 the best way 
to do
> > > it, and which functions may I re-utilize among t=
he many in the
> > > Cantera toolbox.
> > >
> > > The problem is: I would l=
ike to construct a 1 dimensional model
> > able
> > > to reproduce the temp=
erature, velocity and composition profiles
> > along
> > > the axis of the =
reactor as the gas flows through the active 
surface
> > > of charcoal. Sho=
uld I use a single reactor containing ODE 
solution
> > > along the axial c=
o-ordinate or should I link many 0-D reactors
> > > together?
> > > What ab=
out chemical reactions modeling? Mainly, the model should
> > work
> > > wi=
th the following reactions:
> > >
> > > C+2H2<=3D>CH4 ; C+CO2<=3D>2CO; C+H2=
O<=3D>CO+H2; CH4+H2O<=3D>CO+3H2
> > >
> > > Is there in the Cantera tools a=
 kinetic model for these 
reactions?
> > >
> > > Moreover, is there somethi=
ng that I can use to implement a 
model of
> > > biomass pyrolysis?
> > >
>=
 > > Thank you for your help!
> > >
> > > Lorenzo
